\documentclass[english]{article}
\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
\usepackage[latin9]{inputenc}
\usepackage{amsmath}
\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
\title{Derivation of a method for finding the solenoidal part of a vector
field}
\author{Duane Byer}
\date{2019-12-17}

\maketitle
Given a vector field $F$, we wish to find vector fields $A$ and
$D$ that satisfy the following constraints.

\begin{align*}
F & =A+D\\
\nabla\cdot A & =0\\
\nabla\times D & =0
\end{align*}

The field $D$ can be expressed as the gradient of a scalar potential
$\phi$. Using this:

\begin{align*}
\nabla\times\left(\nabla\times F\right) & =\nabla^{2}F-\nabla\left(\nabla\cdot F\right)\\
 & =\nabla^{2}\left(A+D\right)-\nabla\left(\nabla\cdot\left(A+D\right)\right)\\
 & =\nabla^{2}A+\nabla^{2}D-\nabla\left(\nabla\cdot D\right)\\
 & =\nabla^{2}A+\nabla^{2}\left(\nabla\phi\right)-\nabla\left(\nabla^{2}\phi\right)\\
 & =\nabla^{2}A
\end{align*}

This is just Poisson's equation, and it can be solved using a variety
of methods, including Gauss-Seidel.
\end{document}
